author: David McDonnell
title: It might be time for Manchester United to prioritise the Europa League after more dropped points at home
text:
Sport Opinion It might be time for Manchester United to prioritise the Europa League after more dropped points at home With seven Prem draws and a defeat at Old Trafford, winning the UEFA competition is starting to seem like the Reds' best route into next season's Champions League Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Jose Mourinho on Bournemouth draw Share this video   Thank you for subscribing!   
When the dust had settled on a fractious game, Jose Mourinho was forced to acknowledge an uncomfortable truth. 
The running battle between Zlatan Ibrahimovic and Tyrone Mings - and the three-match bans the pair are facing for violent conduct - may have dominated the agenda at Old Trafford. 
But the controversy obscured another missed opportunity for Manchester United to nudge closer to the top-four, a recurring theme that is handicapping Mourinho and his players. 
The 1-1 draw with 10-man Bournemouth means United have dropped 17 points at home this season, seven draws and a defeat undermining their chances of securing a top-four spot and an immediate return to the Champions League. Mourinho looked crestfallen after United failed to beat 10-man visitors Bournemouth (Photo: PA Wire) 
With United three points off fourth and their run-in including trips to top-four rivals Manchester City, Arsenal and Tottenham, their best route back into the Champions League may ultimately be by winning the Europa League. 
Mourinho and his players fly to Russia on Tuesday for Thursday’s last 16 first-leg tie against FC Rostov in a competition that is assuming greater significance for United with every backward step in the Premier League. 
On Saturday it was a familiar story — the Reds dominating but unable to convert the multitude of chances they created, their failure to win even more galling given they played against 10 men for the entire second half. 
Mourinho cut a frustrated figure afterwards, the failure to emerge victorious from what should have been a routine win highlighting the need to buy a proven goal-scorer this summer, with Atletico Madrid’s Antoine Griezmann top of his list. Paul Pogba and co have won less than half of their home league matches (Photo: AFP/Getty) 
“We were punished because in the first-half we played amazingly well and should have been winning 3-0 or 4-0 and in the end - I don’t know how - it was 1-1,” said Mourinho. 
“In the second half, we lost quality in our football, we lost vision in our football, so once more we’re punished in a game we should win. 
“The old story of creating lots of chances and not scoring enough goals is an old story. But it’s a story that applies perfectly to our football in these matches at home. 
“It’s the same story – we start well, we have one chance in the first minute, another in the third or fourth minute and we accumulate chances. 
“Then the goalkeeper gets confidence, is the man of the match and so on and so on. We need to score goals. Other teams with less chances, they score more goals. Top-scorer Ibrahimovic had a penalty saved — and now faces a ban on the run-in (Photo: AFP/Getty) 
“If you look at the points we lost at home, we’re speaking about 10 or 12, then we’re not just speaking about the top four, we’re speaking about the top two. 
“So we lost too many points at home and obviously that’s cost us our position. But are we dead in relation to the top four? No, we’re not dead. 
“There are matches to play, points to win, points to lose, points to fight for, so we’re not dead. But the reality is that we’re losing too many points at home.” 
United went ahead through Marcos Rojo in the 23rd minute, but were pegged back when Josh King converted from the penalty spot after Phil Jones had brought down Marc Pugh. Rojo scored first, but Bournemouth got a draw despite Andrew Surman's red card (Photo: REUTERS) 
The flashpoint between Ibrahimovic and Mings occurred prior to the break, the former elbowing the latter after the Bournemouth defender had earlier trodden on his head. 
Both men escaped punishment, although Cherries skipper Andrew Surman shown a second yellow card for a tame, retaliatory shove on Ibrahimovic after the elbowing incident, the veteran forward tumbling to the ground. 
United are likely to be without the Swede for Premier League games against Middlesbrough and West Brom, as well as the FA Cup quarter-final at Chelsea, if he is banned retrospectively.
